Package io.permazen.annotation

Annotation Type JCompositeIndex

  • @Repeatable(JCompositeIndexes.class)
@Retention(RUNTIME)
@Target({ANNOTATION_TYPE,TYPE})
@Documented
public @interface JCompositeIndex
    Java annotation defining a composite index on all PermazenType-annotated sub-types.

    A composite index is an index on two or more fields (to define a single-field index, just set JField.indexed() to true). All fields indexed in a composite index must be (a) simple and (b) not a sub-field of a complex field.

    @JCompositeIndex is a repeatable annotation. Instances may annotate any @PermazenType-annotated class or supertype thereof. Put another way, instances of a @PermazenType-annotated class that is a subtype of a @JCompositeIndex-annotated type will be included in the corresponding composite index.

    Uniqueness Constraints

    Uniqueness constraints are supported, and their enforcement is handled in the same way as for uniqueness constraints on simply indexed fields (see @JField.unique()). A uniqueness constriant on a composite index means each object's combination of field values must be unique. Specific field value combinations may be excluded from the uniqueness constraint by specifying the corresponding comma-separated String encoded tuples in uniqueExclude().
    See Also:
    PermazenType, JField.indexed()

    • Required Element Summary

      Required Elements 
      Modifier and Type Required Element Description
      String[] fields
      The names of the indexed fields, in the desired order.
      String name
      The name of this composite index.

    • Optional Element Summary

      Optional Elements 
      Modifier and Type Optional Element Description
      int storageId
      The storage ID for this composite index.
      boolean unique
      Require each object's field combination to be unique among all types to which this annotation applies.
      String[] uniqueExclude
      Specify field value combination(s) to be excluded from the uniqueness constraint.

    • Element Detail

      • name

        String name
        The name of this composite index. Must be unique with respect to any indexed Java model type.
        Returns:
        the index name

      • fields

        String[] fields
        The names of the indexed fields, in the desired order. At least two fields must be specified.
        Returns:
        the names of the indexed fields

      • storageId

        int storageId
        The storage ID for this composite index. Value should be positive; if zero, the configured StorageIdGenerator will be consulted to auto-generate a value.
        Returns:
        the index storage ID
        See Also:
        StorageIdGenerator.generateCompositeIndexStorageId()
        Default:
        0

      • unique

        boolean unique
        Require each object's field combination to be unique among all types to which this annotation applies.

        This property creates an implicit uniqueness validation constraint.

        The constraint will be checked any time normal validation is performed on an object. More precisely, a uniqueness constraint behaves like a JSR 303 validation constraint with groups() = { Default.class, UniquenessConstraints.class }. Therefore, uniqueness constraints are included in default validation, but you can also validate only uniqueness constraints via myobj.revalidate(UniquenessConstraints.class).

        Returns:
        whether the composite index's field values should be unique
        See Also:
        uniqueExclude(), UniquenessConstraints
        Default:
        false

      • uniqueExclude

        String[] uniqueExclude
        Specify field value combination(s) to be excluded from the uniqueness constraint.

        The specified values must Strings containing comma-separated encodings of the associated fields.

        Unlike the field values used with @JField.uniqueExclude(), the field values contained here are the self-delimiting string forms.

        For some field types this makes a difference: e.g., String values must be surrounded by double quotes. For example: 

         @PermazenType(compositeIndexes =
  @JCompositeIndex(name = "firstAndLast", fields = { "lastName", firstName" },
                      unique = true, uniqueExclude = "\"Unknown\", \"Unknown\""))
  public abstract class Person {

      public abstract String getLastName();
      public abstract void setLastName(String x);

      public abstract String getFirstName();
      public abstract void setFirstName(String x);
  }

        To specify a null value in the list, specify the self-delimiting string form of the null value (this is almost always the string "null"): 

         @PermazenType(compositeIndexes =
  @JCompositeIndex(name = "firstAndLast", fields = { "lastName", firstName" },
                      unique = true, uniqueExclude = "null, null"))
  public abstract class Person {

      public abstract String getLastName();
      public abstract void setLastName(String x);

      public abstract String getFirstName();
      public abstract void setFirstName(String x);
  }

        This property must be left empty when unique() is false.

        Returns:
        value combinations to exclude from the uniqueness constraint
        See Also:
        unique()
        Default:
        {}
